Two months ago I started a new role building and maintaining a Vue 2 application. As we set our sights on 2023 - we‚Äôve started to ask ourselves what a next-gen Vue 3 application might look like. What has changed in the industry over the past few years? What are the industry's best practices?
Most importantly (at this stage), how do we organize our code in an elegant way that adheres to Vue‚Äôs style guide?
During my research, I noticed a handful of patterns and practices that stood out - especially from the perspective of organization:
The entrypoint is split into separate files
It uses next-gen state management (hint: Pinia)
It makes heavy use of composables
1. The entrypoint is split into separate files
In Vue, the entrypoint is responsible for bootstrapping the app and setting up the main Vue instance. It might be named
main.ts
c
index.ts
c
app-setup.ts
c
, etc. In a large and complex application, it can get a little out of hand to keep adding bootstrap functions to this single file as your application and its dependencies grow.

In the examples I looked at, it was common practice to split this file into smaller files organized by functionality/dependency. Generally, this allows for better readability, easier debugging, and an overall cleaner structure.
I found the naming convention for where these were located to be interesting. In some instances it was
/plugins/
c
while in others it was
/modules/
c
. I‚Äôd love to find more examples to solidify my own preference, but in the end it‚Äôs all personal/team preference.
vue3-realworld-example-app/src/plugins at master ¬∑ mutoe/vue3-realworld-example-app

title: I‚Äôve been a longtime fan of Gatsby. About a year ago I joined a team that deploys Gatsby-based sites to Kubernetes. Since then, I‚Äôve been chasing after the best (and maybe cheapest) way to implement incremental builds in a production environment. You might think of it as a self-hosted alternative to the major providers like Gatsby Cloud, Netlify, Vercel, etc.

An incremental build is a build of Gatsby that generates only the subset of HTML files that needed to be updated based on the changes made to the site. Changes to page templates, page queries, static queries, and frontend source code cause HTML files to be marked for regeneration.

Basically, your CMS sends a POST call to a given web-hook when things change and triggers a build on the infrastructure/backend side. The challenge is - build infrastructure isn‚Äôt easily available in OSS. It‚Äôs unclear* how the major providers manage the web-hooks and build Gatsby sites. It‚Äôs especially interesting when you get to providers like Gatsby Cloud who claim to rebuild (incrementally) at numbers like 1-5 seconds.
*Netlify is a huge exception in that, a lot of their infrastructure is surprisingly available on GitHub
i
There are several reasons why implementing incremental builds in a production environment is important for Gatsby-based sites.

First, incremental builds can significantly improve the performance and scalability of your site. By only regenerating the HTML files that have been changed, you can reduce the time and resources required for each build.

Second, incremental builds can also help you save money by reducing the cost of hosting and deploying your site. By making your builds more efficient, you can reduce the number of resources and infrastructure needed to support your site, which can save you money on hosting fees and other costs.

In summary, implementing incremental builds in a production environment is an important step for any Gatsby-based site, and can provide significant benefits in terms of performance, scalability, cost savings, and user experience.
A webhook that builds Gatsby via an Express endpoint with a FIFO queue.

I‚Äôm sure we could commit a .vscode folder - but there is something unnerving about that.

Pre-commit Hook ¬∑ Prettier

I spent the last five days in Portland alongside four awesome colleagues at DrupalCon 2022. It was an awesome experience to be back in-person with such a diverse crowd of passionate people.
Of all the things I learned this week, my overall takeaway is: stay humble
b
ü§î
Open-source is at the frontline of innovation in the DEI space ‚ù§Ô∏è

While there were multiple keynotes centered around the idea of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in the workplace - the one that really hit home is embedded below. In it, three unique individuals present three different perspectives on global systems of oppression in the tech industry.

Each of them presented difficult, yet concrete ideas around combatting global oppression. Overall, I walked away with the idea that this is just the beginning of a long road to restructure our processes.
I especially enjoyed the what was presented by Daelyn Moyer. I highly recommend you watch the video.

In some projects, like our flagship project at Duke, your Gatsby project might become overwhelming large. What happens when you want to add another tool to it? Should you increase the complexity and organization of your project? What if you could split it out into its own repo? Should you?
Storybook is an open source tool for building UI components and pages in isolation. It streamlines UI development, testing, and documentation.
Shadowing is a powerful tool. It is a necessity in order to adopt the influx of developers moving from the CMS space to the Jamstack ecosystem.  I‚Äôll leave
their documentation for the work of ‚Äúhow‚Äù
a
https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/how-to/plugins-and-themes/shadowing/
and jump into what your project might look like as a shadowed Storybook project.

/
|-- /.storybook
		|-- fsMock.js
		|-- main.js
		|-- preview.js
|-- /stories
    |-- Follow your component folder's structure here.
|-- gatsby-config.js
Get the easy parts over with üòä
The folks at Gatsby have written enough to get us going. The important parts are to add your parent project in
gatsby-config.js
c
and scaffold out the must-have storybook configuration files.
Now, let‚Äôs get to the real challenge
This isn‚Äôt 100% the end-all be-all solution, as most aren‚Äôt. This is simply what I discovered while trying to do this myself.
I‚Äôve been using a forked version of
‚Ä£
eoi
03120ff2-f9b5-4f11-a39d-3fb2f10719cd

for a while now and I have never been happier with my personal website. I start writing ideas left and right - so much so that it may even need its own little graveyard section for the blog ideas I have and never fulfill‚Ä¶ However, that‚Äôs really the point. Notion is such a flexible platform that I can add, remove, tag, and reorganize to my heart‚Äôs content.
I've spent far too much time trying to start, build, and perfect my portfolio for years. It seems like every year I spin up a project titles things like
portfolio20
c
and
portfolio21
c

and I never have felt satisfied by my own work. Deciding on a design, adding unique functionality, showoff the latest trends... Yeah - I've got a Notion page full of examples and ideas. Maybe I'll share that in the future.

One of my biggest hurdles has always been writing content. For whatever reason, trying to lay out content on my own portfolio always proves to be a challenge. Everyone knows that content is king. That is why, I'm
focusing on content creation.
b
I've been using Notion for some time and it hit me - why am I not using it as a stopgap and a mechanism to write more freely and easily. Not to mention, it looks badass.
It's not all flowers and roses
s
I don't know whether or not it can be crawled by search engines and mobile isn't very responsive (at least from a few quick tests).
s
When the time comes, I can always export and import my blog posts. Or better yet, I can continue use Notion as a CMS with a Gatsby frontend... üßê

I recently came across a very powerful tool that allows us developers to leave behind the second-guessing nature of ‚ÄúI changed x, did it break in y?‚Äù
BackstopJS will save your ass. Let me show you how easy it is to use.
Install BackstopJS globally: npm install -g backstopjs or yarn global add backstopjs
Change into a directory that will host the files and run:
backstop init
c
All good?
b
Approve the test so that it now becomes the reference:
backstop approve
c
So what might a real config look like?
You might find that it is easier to abstract out an array of scenarios into its own JavaScript file, like
scenarios.js
c
. In which case, you should look into using a JS based config file as described in this
example
a
https://github.com/garris/BackstopJS/tree/master/examples/jsBasedConfig
Now, your backstopConfig.js file might include:
b

While working on a site recently, I dove headfirst into Sage 9. It was an amazing experience that I‚Äôll document later. One trivial note I wanted to enforce in the land of Google and searching for common problems is the fix I found when deploying Sage 9 to WPEngine.

pi_mont

https://discourse.roots.io/t/sage-9-on-wpengine/9090/24
on the Sage 9 forum

/*
|----------------------------------------------------------------------

|----------------------------------------------------------------------

*/

'compiled' => '/tmp/sage-cache',
// 'compiled' => wp_upload_dir()['basedir'].'/cache',

DeveloperWeek was a blast and I‚Äôm very thankful I had the opportunity to go. Shoutout to Sherry Bastion, my manager, for sending me out there! This was my first big conference as as a newbie in the workforce. Overall I was pleased with how it turned out.

This opportunity made it clear that my next conference should specific towards a community I want to engage with (such as React, Gatsby, or JavaScript). The spectrum of speakers and sessions at DeveloperWeek varied from basic and beginner concepts (someone walked through what NPM was‚Ä¶) to highly specific concepts that might never cross my desk. I enjoyed the mix, as I bounced around session-to-session.

I packed my schedule full of 50 sessions (some overlapping) and charged ahead for three days. Thank god for the Peet‚Äôs Coffee next door, shout out to them. Some of my favorite sessions were in the Product World and DevExec tracks. These high level discussions provided a break from the highly-specific implementations of ideas and tools in JavaScript that I often wonder when I would use.
Of those 50 sessions, the ones that stood out to me were:
Adopting Agile Anywhere and Everywhere: From the Cloud to the Enterprise
a
https://developerweek2020.sched.com/event/YXSQ/pro-workshop-adopting-agile-anywhere-and-everywhere-from-the-cloud-to-the-enterprise#
by Skyla Loomis
The Ignored Voices in Product Design: Your Development Team
a
https://developerweek2020.sched.com/event/YbHn/productworld-pro-session-the-ignored-voices-in-product-design-your-development-team#
by Peter Pezaris
One Team, One Dream? Gaining Cross-Functional Buy-In
a
https://developerweek2020.sched.com/event/ZdDh/productworld-pro-session-one-team-one-dream-gaining-cross-functional-buy-in#
by Caroling Lee
From Coding to Managing: What I‚Äôve Learned so Far
a
https://developerweek2020.sched.com/event/YF2E/pro-session-from-coding-to-managing-what-ive-learned-so-far#
by Israel Heringer

https://developerweek2020.sched.com/event/YF7q/pro-session-progressive-web-apps-are-the-future#

https://developerweek2020.sched.com/event/YbHW/pro-session-webops-how-developers-and-marketers-deliver-great-digital-experiences#
by Josh Koenig

hackathon

https://www.developerweek.com/events/hackathon/

, I also understand that preparation and planning will push me to bring the value my team deserves. In my next post, I‚Äôll outline the known challenges from each sponsor and strategize/brainstorm some solutions.

Back in February, my team was tasked with updating the content on the Sensus Reach site, a site that promotes and supports our annual utility conference. While gathering requirements from internal stakeholders, it became apparent that more time would be spent working in the nuances of
The Keynote
i
, a WordPress theme, than it would take to build an entirely new site from the ground up.

Additionally, it became clear that the site really didn‚Äôt need WordPress behind it. The content was minimal and infrequently changed. When content was to be changed, it fell on our team anyway. Thus eliminating the need for any sort of page-builder administration functionality. With this in mind, I started pitching the idea of a static site, one that didn‚Äôt need a database nor a server-side language like PHP.

Well, I guess ‚Äúhero‚Äù is a little stretch for such a simple tool, but that‚Äôs how it felt after a week into development. Our strategy was simple: get a design planned out and develop it immediately.
Jekyll
a
https://jekyllrb.com/
allowed us to build a static website in HTML using
Bootstrap
a
https://getbootstrap.com/

, a framework everyone is familiar with, in no time. When development steered towards the inner-most pages, we found that Jekyll allowed us to standardize a template with ease. Our data came from Markdown files, allowing us to use YAML, called
Front Matter
a
https://jekyllrb.com/docs/front-matter/
, to conveniently build custom fields with minimal configuration.

Jekyll‚Äôs convenience provided us with the means to generate pages, build navigation menus, use conditional logic in HTML templates, and organize our files in a meaningful way. Its clear syntax allowed us to go from
zero to hero
b
in under a month.
My eyes were set on
Gatsby
a
https://www.gatsbyjs.com/
from the moment the project came to fruition. I wanted to pitch it early on, but I knew the tight deadline would be inappropriate for such an experiment.
I had to wait for the next iteration of the site. Fortunately for me, that iteration has begun. I look forward to detailing my venture into Gatsby in a future post. In the meantime,
have you used Jekyll on any projects? Is Jekyll still relevant in 2020? What pitfalls have you found in Jekyll?
b
How to properly plan a application rewrite?
Why you should put time into planning
b

Imposter syndrome effects everyone differently, from the occasional thought of self-doubt to persistent internal fears. Imposter syndrome was first coined in an article published in 1978, titled "The Impostor Phenomenon in High Achieving Women: Dynamics and Therapeutic Intervention.‚Äù
persistent doubt concerning one's abilities or accomplishments
the fear of being exposed as a fraud despite evidence of one's ongoing success
In my (albeit brief) experience - imposter syndrome is easily beaten with the right attitude, a winning one.
What does imposter syndrome feel like?
Describe how imposter syndrome can impact self-confidence and self-esteem
Discuss how it can lead to stress and anxiety
Explain how it can prevent people from reaching their full potential
So‚Ä¶ how exactly does attitude help?
Discuss how a positive attitude can help combat negative thoughts and beliefs associated with imposter syndrome

I'm a Software Engineer with a deep-rooted passion for crafting exceptional user experiences and web solutions. Over time, I've come to recognize that my expertise could truly make a difference for others in need of assistance with their online presence.

With this in mind, I've recently decided to extend my services beyond my regular work hours to support friends, family, and small businesses within my community. My goal is to help them overcome common web development challenges and enhance their online footprint, using my skills in WordPress updates, plugin management, content updates, website backups, security monitoring, and minor customization projects.
If you're in search of a helping hand for your web development needs, I'm here to assist you on this journey, providing personalized solutions tailored to your unique requirements.
WordPress Updates
b
Keep your WordPress site up-to-date with the latest versions.
Plugin Management
b
Manage plugin updates and ensure compatibility with your site.
Content Updates
b
Add, update, or remove content on your website as needed.
Website Backups
b
Regularly back up your website to prevent data loss.
Security Monitoring
b
Monitor your website for security threats and vulnerabilities.
Minor Customization Projects
b
Make minor customizations and improvements to your website.

I'm truly excited to help family, friends, and small businesses in our community thrive with their online presence. If you're interested in my services and would like to discuss how I can assist you, please don't hesitate to reach out to me:
